content.question: A particle moves in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane so that its position at any time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by the parametric functions <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x prime of t, equals, open parenthesis, t minus 1, close parenthesis, times, e raised to the t squared power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y prime of t, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, 3 minus, 3 times t squared, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>. What is the total distance traveled by the particle from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 1.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.6: (BC ONLY) Solving Motion Problems Using Parametric and Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
